div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South, and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

TO secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1907..

div.head: NATIONALISM IN CYPRUS.
div.p: In a telegram from Larnaca, which we publish to-day, it is stated that Mr. Winston Churchill has given a highly satisfactory reply to the Cypriot Nationalists. The visit of the Under Secretary of State for the Colonies to that island was considered a good opportunity by both Turks and Greeks to vent their political ideas, and we hope the Moslems of Egypt will bear in mind that is was their co-religionists in Cyprus, who bore witness to their loyalty to Britain and to their contentment under our rule. The Turks are well aware what their position would be if the island were handedover to Greece and at the same time they are by no means desirous of reverting to the Sultan's rule, for they are too near to Asia Minor and Syria to be ignorant of the results of Ottoman misrule. But the Turks are only 51,000 in number, as against the 182,000 Greeks and it is the latter who are always agitating for union with Athens. This idea is part and parcel of the same political theory, which has already done so much harm to Greece. It led them on to declare war against Turkey, which is now acknowledged by all Greeks to have been a serious mistake. It obliges them to make claims in Macedonia such as will prevent any satisfactory settlement of the problem of that land. This obsession of Hellenic Nationalism, however grandoise in theory, is quite unworkable in practical politics and it will always be one of the chief sources of political disquietude in the Levant, because it is so essentially impracticable. However much we may sympathise with the political ambitions of the Hellenic race,-and they must acknowledge that England has ever been their champion,-the Foreign Office is well aware of the recalcitrance of the Greek Members of the Cypriot Legislative Council and their continual opposition to the Administration does not tend to increase our inclination to materially advance Hellenic interests in other parts of the Mediterranean.

The demands of the Greeks of Cyprus for union with kingdom of Greece are politically impossible, as we could not agree to any such policy without deliverately violating the Anglo-Ottoman Convention of 1878. Even if this difficulty were obviated, it would be financially impossible for us to accede to the claims. Greece is not in a position to bear the burthen of the Tribute, for every year since the convention was signed, with the exception of three years, we have been obliged to vote considerable sums towards making up the deficiency in aid of the administration of Cyprus. For the year 1903-1904 Parliament voted £87,000 for this purpose and the failure of the island to meet the full annual burthen of £92,800 has been met by grants from the British Treasury, averaging £30,000 per annum. Moreover from our own point of view there is no reason why we should hand over the island to please Greek sentiment, as we have spent considerable sums on its improvement. Owing to the initiative of Mr. Chamberlain Parliament recently sanctioned a grant in aid of the revenues of £50,000 for three years and a loan of £315,000 for irrigation, as well as a harbour and railway loans, and the port of Famagusta has been dredged and reconstructed at a cost of £126,000. This port might be of some considerable strategic value in case of a war. For example if the Akaba question had had to be decided by force of arms, the defence of Egypt through Syria would have been an easy matter because of our hold over Cyprus. In any future invasion of Egypt the strategic position of Cyprus would be a very valuable asset. However, there is no need to discuss the matter further. We are in Cyprus and we intend to remain there and as long as we hold India, Egypt, Malta, and Gibraltar, we shall hold Cyprus, and the Power which will obtain the reversion of that island will not be Greece. It will be the Power which obtains the reversion of our Eastern Empire and our Mediterranean possessions, Egypt included. The sooner the Nationalists of Cyprus and Egypt are able to grasp this simple fact, the better for their peace of mind.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: A telegram from Port Said reports the occurence of a case of plague in that town.

div.head: Nile Valley Crushing.
div.p: Nile Valley (New) - During the month of September the battery crushed 1,056 tons for a yield of 450 ozs.

div.head: Pilgrimage Regulation
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior have published an order dealing with the conditions and rules to be observed on the occasion of the next pilgrimage.

div.head: The Mehallah School.
div.p: Ali Bey Menzalawi has given L.E. 10 to the Benevolent Islamic Society. The sum is to be devoted to the purchase of clothing for the poor pupils of Mehalleh School

div.head: Ports and Lights.
div.p: The Council of Discipline of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration has ordered the dismissal of Ali Effendi Hassan, Muahiz of the Administration workshops, for having been guilty of fraud. This decision has been confirmed by the special Council of Discipline of the Ministry of Finance.

div.head: Buried Alive.
div.p: A report comes from Shibin el Kom of the burial of a young girl while still alive. It was not until all the funeral rites had been observed and the people were about to leave the grave-side, that the father heard sounds coming from the grave. The coffin was speedily uncovered and the girl rescued from a terrible death.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: On the proposal of the Director-General of the Public Health Department, the Minister of the Interior has authorised Drs. Frank Smeeton Matlack, Bishara Yusuf Abdul and Isaac Joseph to practice their profession in Egypt; also Mrs. Rose Emelie Soumagnac as midwife, and Mr. Panayotis E. Nicolaou as pharmaceutist.

div.head: The Paris Police Force.
div.p: Mr. Lepine, the well-known prefect of the Parisian police force, has decided to have the members of the force instructed in foreign languages. Quite naturally the task of instruction has been confided to the Berlitz School. Here is an idea which might profitably be taken up for the benefit of our shawishes and might especially, at this moment of the influx of tourists, prevent so many misunderstandings. [Advt]

div.head: Fall Of A House.
div.p: There is yet another instance of the unsafe condition of some of the poorer class dwelling houses recorded in Cairo. At 10 a.m. yesterdau a house in the Sharia Farawells. Abdenn, collapsed burying a woman in its debris. Fortunately she was rescued almost immediately and was found to have sustained only slight bruises, which will, however, ncessitate her remaining for treatment in hospital for about 10 days.

div.head: Moslems and Christians
div.p: At the Church Congress last week Mr. J.T. Hotblack, of the Norwich Diocesan Conference, said the advantage of the Moslems was that they treated inferior races as equal, whereas Europeans acted with a brutal discourtesy. This was a great difficulty. The Moslem merchant was an admirable missionary of his faith tour merchant was the worst. Here was an evil to be remedied. In Egypt we had-if we would use it-a valuable ally in the Coptic Church, from which our own professors might well learn.

div.head: The Inniskilling Fusillers
div.p: The 2nd Battn. of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, who are shortly leaving for Alexandria are giving a grand farewell concert at the Grand Continental Hotel on Saturday night next under the conductorship of Mr. R. Watson Ramsey. They will perform during dinner, and afterwards will give a concert on the terrace. Their music has been much appreciated during their sojourn in the town, and we expect that there will not be many of their admirers absent on Saturday when they will heard, unfortunately, for the last time. The programme of the music to be played will be published in due course.

div.head: A SUDANESE BLUEBEARD
div.p: A remarkable story from Minet el Gamh is related in the columns of a native comtemporary, according to which a Sudanese of that village, who has been married eight times, has got rid of all his wived by murdering them and hiding their bodies. The last lady who met her fate in this way was the daughter of a certain Said Ahmed Awad, and before murdering her, Bluebeard Mohamed Abou Mandour gave her the choice of death by fire, knife, revolver, or nabout. No choice was made, however, and, so the story runs, the Bluebeard cut the lady's throat. The murder, however, was discovered and a large force of police proceeded to the man's house and placed him under arrest.

div.head: NOTICE TO POLO PLAYERS.
div.p: Polo players are informed that owing to the Polo ground being watered there will be no polo on Thursday the 17th inst. Polo players will be allowed to play on Monday next the 21st. inst.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter

div.head: DJELALLEDIN'S LETTER
INDIGNATION AT VILDIZ
THE PASHA'S RETURN DEMANDED
div.p: London, Tuesday.

The "Times" Constantinople correspondent states that Ahmed Djelladin's letter criticising the Porte has caused great indignation at Yildiz. According to report the Sultan has wired to the Khedive expressing his surprise and indignation, and requesting the Khedive to summon the Pasha to an audience and insist upon his immediate return to Constantinople.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive received m private audience yesterday morning at Ras el Tin palace Mr. Alexander Powell, U.S. Consul, and afterwards presided over the Council of Ministers.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: At yesterday's meeting of the Council of Ministers, presided over by the Khedive, the following decisions were made:-
(1) The appointment of Mr. H. P. Harvey as member of the Superior Council of Education.
(2) The appointment of Mr. S. H. Wells as member of the Scientific Committee of the Ministry of Education.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: A French newspaper recently declared that Lord Cromer's scheme for the reform of the capitulations in Egypt had been abandonded. We are in a position to state that there is no truth in this report.

div.head: EDUCATION MINISTRY BUDGET.
div.p: An important meeting of the Superior Council of Public Instruction was held yesterday morning, Mr. Dunlop presiding in the absence of and by request of Saad Pasha Zagloul, the Minister of Education. The subject under discussion was the Budget for 1908, and proposals for increasing the Budget for 1907 by an augmentation of L.E. 100,000 were unanimously approved.

div.head: DELTA BARRAGE INCIDENT.
STEALING OF FLOWERS.
div.p: A few days ago a Cairo comtemporary recorded an incident which occured recently at the Barrage, and in doing so cast grave reflections upon the conduct of Mr. W. Draper, as having abused his authority as director of the gardens. We find, however, upon careful enquiry that the incident had been most inaccurately reported, and we therefore give the true facts of the case, which have been stated to us as follows:-

On the morning of Sunday the 6th inst. Mr. Draper saw a party of ladies with a youth and a girl (to all appearances considerably over the age of 5) picking flowers from a climbing plant in the Government Gardens. Each had a handful of blosson, and one of the party was wearing red roses stolen from the Gardens. On a policeman on duty a short distance away being called, some of the ladies threw down their flowers, and others hid them in the folds of their dresses and sunshades.

The flowers in question were pink (Antigonon) growing too high for a small child to reach. Mr. Draper left the party with the policeman, and sent the park keeper in uniform to them. The park keeper states that he gave the ladies the usual alternative of paying P.T. 20 for damage, which they refused, saying the flowers were picked by a child, and they went to the police station a short distance away.

Visitors stealing flowers and plants from the Government Gardens have become a nuisance. They are usually very uncivil both to the officials and the gardeners if spoken to, and the latter they often charge the offence. For this purpose a policeman is stationed on duty in the grounds and any cases caught are handed over to him. One has, we are told, only to be at the railway station for the departure of a crowded train to see the large percentage of people with flowers stolen from the gardens, to understand the difficulty there is in preventing theft and damage, in spite of the rules being posted up in three languages and the efforts of the park keeper and police.

div.head: OMDEH FOUND DEAD.
SUSPECTED CASE OF MURDER.
div.p: News was brought to the Ministry of the Interior this morning that the Omdeh of Abou Hommar had been found dead in a field near his village. He is supposed to have been murdered, though no reason is assigned for the fact. An enquiry is of course to be immediately opened.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
REGATTA.
div.p: The handicap and times of starting for tomorrow's regatta are the same as last week:- Class I and Rating Class.-Course D. Class II.- Course N.

div.head: CHURCHILL'S VOYAGE EAST.
PASSAGE THROUGH CANAL
div.p: Port Said, Monday.

As I wired you this morning H.M.S. "Venus" arrived here this morning at 11.40 a.m. with Mr. Winston Churchill on board. Immediately on arrival the "Venus" took bunkers and proceeded immediately into the Canal. Mr. D. A. Cameron, H.B.M.'s Consul paid an official visit.
Suez, Tuesday.
H.M.S. "Venus" has just arrived here with Mr. Winston Churchill aboard and is proceeding without anchoring.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
THE LIBERALS AND KAMEL
div.p: Much comment has been aroused in Cairo by the fact that Mustapha Pasha Kamel continues to maintain complete silence in regard to the serious charges, which have been brought against of deceiving public opinion. Lately the leader of the Egyptian Liberal Party, Mohamed Wahid Bey, in a Cairo vernacular newspaper declared that the manifestation in honour of Kamel's arrival at Cairo station, which the "Egyptian Standard" qualified as "epochmaking" was a pure fake as the crowd consisted of printers employed on his newspapers and pupils of the Khedivial Law School and that the pretention that the manifestants consisted of notables and other well-known natives was absurd. It was thought that these accusations would have been disproved, but no reply has been given.
PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS AND THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
"Al Watan" says:-

Among those who were loud in their clamour for parliamentary institutions of late certain members of the present Legislative Council were prominently heard. These gentlemen will in all probability form part of the coming Parliament of Egypt if that instutition is destined to make its appearance during the span of their lives. It is interesting, therefore, to study the manner in which they are now performing their duty to their country as members of the body called together to give advice to the Government on the most important questions of legislation. As the Government has always shown genuine willingness to follow sound advice and to act on the wish of the Legislative Council whenever, that Council gave its opinion without bias and with a sincere desire to serve the interests of the people, we can find no apology for any member of the said Council who shows apathy or want of interest in the work of his country. We may also take it for granted that a member of the Legislative Council as now constituted who takes no interest in its work is not likely to prove more active or interested in the work of legsialtion were his country to be granted a constitution in the near future.

Now, a mere glance at the minutes of the Council's sittings will prove to any mind that the majority of its members are absolutely indifferent and perhaps unsympathetic, entertaining no visible desire to attend the sittings of the COuncil or to take the least part in its work. Ever and anon we are told that the Legislative Council opened its doors on a certain date fixed for a sitting but the sitting did not take the place owing to the absence of members. The business of the day, sometimes of an urgent nature, has it consequence of this recurrent absence to be postponed and the apathetic Councilors have to be summoned a second, and perhaps a third time before they can be seen together for a day or two and induced to dispatch business of the greatest importance. Indeed, the absence of members from the sittings of the Legislative Council has become chronic and may damage the national claim for a stepforward in representative government.

Again, the discussions of these members, if ever they stoop to a show of discussion on any subject of common interest, are most discouraging. The greatest questions are dealt with by one or two remarks and a hasty vote. Others are merely read and coted in a moment without the humblest show of pains or interest by our legislators. We have never heard yet of a member who studied any subject in particular and discussed it in detail among his brother Councillors or gave his advise to the Government after elaborate research. That these members, with their surprising lethargy and inactivity should think of themselves better entitled to legislate for Egypt than the eminent servants of the State, or that they should claim more power for the Council to which they belong is certainly not in favour of a hasty approach towards the national goal.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Papayanni liner S.S. "Alexandria" left Malta yesterday and is due here on the 18th inst., with passengers and mails.
The Papayanni liner "City of Cambridge" which left on the 30th ult. arrived at Liverpool yesterday.
The S.S. "Egyptian Prince" sailed on Saturday last for Manchester with general cargo including 8,475 bales of cotton.
The S.S. "Oreste Prince" arrived from Antwerp and London on Sunday with general cargo and passengers.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: *M Lambert has added to the number of Mr. Dunlop's enemies,' says a Cairo contemporary, —we agree, with the addition that the ex Director of the Khedivial Law School has irretrievably injured hie own reputation as an administrator and as a man. We should bare Added as a lawyer' were it not for the fact that legal theory has been M Lambert's interest to the exclusion of legal practice ft fa an well for him. To judge from his amazing conduct of a very fair case, and hie even more extraordinary attack upon hit own character, he could scarcely have expected to shine at the Bar. What has M. Lambert to tell us that it supported by evidence , wliat ground law he for his vague talas of how Sir Eldon (Jorat may or may not have said thia, or that, and how Mr Dunlop told him at an unspecified time to falsify an unopened document in an nnspeci-tied dossier t Where are the proofs, the copies of these orders, of the instructions communicated by the Machiavellian adviser to the pitiable professor I Really, when reading these naif outpouring* on the part of the ex-Di rec tor we begin to sympathise with the Ministry of Education and to share in the enthusiasm with which his resignation was accepted

Mr Lambert tells his story with eloquence and fervour, And the "anti-European elements" of ' the Opposition, we quote M. Lambert, applaud him non brio. So vigorous is their applause, so strong the detestation of the accused Adviser, so distressing the plaints of the wronged exDirector that all critical faculty is paralysed and nineteen^wenrieths the Press joins in one great shout of "Down with Dunlop.' Criticism in the person of "Le Progres is adjured in die name of the devil of the ever courteous "Egyptian Standard to say what more it wants and the comments of educated Egypt are themselves crueller commentaries on the value of the instruction imported in our schools than any of M. lamberts declarations.

According to the exDirector of the Law School, Mr. Dunlop, whose rigid formalism in regard to rules and regulations had already caused a strike, continued to harass the students whom he drove in increasing numbers into the camp of the anti European opposition. M Lambert regretted this, he complained to Mr. Dunlop without result. Mr. Dunlop did not confine himself to persecution of the natives, he persecuted and drove ont the French and other professors, replacing them by 'young fellows' fresh from English Universities. True, all these 'young fellows' had practised at the bar and some had done original work of high quality. Still that, did not matter to M. Lambert, for him they were 'young fellows' to be sneered at by their loyal colleague. In the midst of these horrors Saad Pasha Zaghloul was appointed to he Minister of Public Instruction by the British Agency, in "deference to public opinion'' which had never as far as we arc aware advocated his appointment to anything at all. Mr Dunlop, wicked man, saw in him an obstacle to his autocracy and was for a moment in despair. But the resourcefulness of this wicked under liner of melodrama did not fail him, He pressed his subordinates into a conspiracy, doubtless with dire threats of rustication or compulsory retirement! Why did not M. lambert give us the description of the harrowing scene. Dr. Keatinge, Messrs. Boyd Carpenter, Sharman Elliot, Dr. Mackenzie and himself being com-polled to swear awful oaths of secrecy and obedience M. Lambert, poor man, was obviously unnerved by the over mastering will power of the Adviser His conscience troubled him amazingly, the more so as he did not like Mr. Dunlop and his ways at all, and had on that account, no doubt,been dragged into the plot as the vulgar put it by "the short hairs."

Every conspirator in melodrama, especially the wicked underling, forces his deadliest enemies tn swear fidelity and to conspire with him against the virtuous and great, so M. Lambert followed the classical rules and swore —his conscience still protesting. The Adviser with his myrmidons now opened a campaign against the Minister M. Lambert was compelled by the wicked underling to hide the truth from the hero of the tragi comedy. His conscience pricked him sorely but he stifled it. His intelligence, doubtless benumbed by Mr. Dunlop's spells, failed to counsel him to appeal to Caesar in the person of the French or British Diplomatic Agents. Mr Dunlop bade him alter reports—in the Chinese formula M Lambert "tremblingly obeyed." His conscience protested in vain, his intelligence failed to suggest to him that it would be a good plan to note the alterations "for future reference." Mr. Dunlop then ordered the unhappy slave of his tyrannous ambitions to falsify filed and register ed documenta, just as the winded underling turns on his accomplice to forge a will with intent to prove that the hero bis master is a bastard and he himself the rightful heir. M lambert's con science was vastly perturbed. So was Candida's at a certain exciting moment during his Persian travels. But Candida feared death like a philosopher, and M. Lambert apparently feared dismissal, — like an official.

Shortly afterwards M. Lambert came to the conclusion that he had truckled too much to Mr. Dunlop. So when the wicked underling broke his promises to him, his myrmidon hit the table with his fist and vowed he would resign unless he got two native professors for the Law School. A "highly placed British Official" intervened, and be got them. Tragic scene! The underling's underling exclamatory, the wicked underling gloomy and threatening, the noble patron who has an interest in the lesser of the villains composing the strife.
Here again M. Lambert gives us too little. We should have expected some thing like this:-
U.U. Unless thou givest me professot twain, I shall resign-

W.V. Hold hard! Vile insolent wretch, Dost thou remember how the will was forged That made me master of the Ministry? Whose brain composed, whose pen wrote down in ink The -emendations that I bade thee make?
U.U. Why mine-
W.U. They hold they peace-
etc.

The noble patron got the Director his professors, but to continue the language of romance the wicked underling signified to this understrapper, that he must pay for the concession which he did: It was thusa number of honest young Egyptians were applying for teacherships at Saad Pasha Zagloul's urgent request -published in the official journal. M. Lambert was instructed to report unfavorably on their capacity, just as the second villain in the piece is bidden to murder the innocent palatial mansion. Moat second villains refuse— M Lambert's conscience urged him to follow their example, his intelligence apparently gave ont completely under this new strain and feared death like a philosopher—well—Candide the right about and M Lambert with the air of a man who could suffer no more waited for the inevitable. It came at last - the nefarious Adviser bad made a dishonorable tool of M Lambert, he had taught him to forge documenta, to sack deserving candidates, to conspire against a Minister and to conceal the truth from the world in general He now made him look rididculous. The chivalrous blood of the Director was fired by the insult—he had obliged the Adviser with a submissiveness worthy of an early Xtian, but when the W U. began to play clownish tricks upon him, he renounced his service and fled, to give belated information of his complicity in numerous crimes to the rightful heir and the Egyptian public. The reception (Act. III last scene) of this was "immense" an the Yankees say. The villain was hissed by the gallery, the pit and the boxes, and the pit laid they knew it all along and what a fool the hero was to betaken in so easily. We have no space for the present to discuss his less romantic charges against the Adviser Meanwhile he has approached the naivete of Mr. Harry Orchard, who after blow ing up a vast number of persons with bombs at the behest of a wicked labour leader, found his conscience prick him and blew the gaff. The Jury found the labor leader not guilty— arguing that it was hard to believe in a phenomenon like Harry Orchard. We can say the same of M. Lambert.

div.head: WESTERN OASIS RAILWAY.
div.p: The passenger carriages, built by the Metropolitan Amalgamated Railway Carriage and Wagon Company Limited for the Corporation of Western Egypt's new railway have been shipped from England by the S.S. "Clydesdale."

Messrs. Gusman and Dentemaro, Contractors of Sharia el Boulac, to whom the arduous work of preparing the formation for the new road was entrusted, having now completed their work, propose giving a fantasia on a large scale to their, and the Company's employes in celebration of the event at Qara.
The fantasia which is to totake place on the 20th inst. will comprise the following events:-
10 a.m. Air gun Competition, Nabout Fencing (natives), Fantasia and Natvie Dances.
12 a.m. Lunch

2.30 p.m. Donkey Race (natives), Carnel, Race, Long Jump (Europeans), Putting the Shot, High Jump, Pigeon Shotting, 100 yds flat race, Boxing show, Tug of War, (all for Europeans), Distribution of prizes, Flying of paper Balloons, Venitian Illumination.
6.30-7.30 Interval.
7.30 p.m. Dinner, to be followed by Fireworks and the Theatrical Entertainment (if available).
Prizes will be given for the various events and a champion prize will be awarded to the winner of the greatest number of points.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Hassan Pasha Mohsen and his family arrived from Europe yesterday.
Rear-Admiral, Sir Massie Blomfield is expected back next Monday.
Mansfield Tasha arrived in Cairo yesterday morning.
Sir William Willcocks paid a visit to the British Agency yesterday morning.
Chitty Bey will arrive at Port Said tomorrow by the Brindisi mail boat.
Mr. Alexander Powell, U.S. Consul, who arrived yesterday by the "Schleswig" has taken up his quarters for the winter at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.
Mr. Jules Ricard, Agent-General of the Messageries Maritimes Company, is staying at the Carlton Hotel.
Count Kodziebrodski, Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, is due back in Egypt on the 28th inst.
Mr. John Joannides, Manager in Egypt of the Bank of Athens, and Mrs. Joannides arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Greece.
Major J. F. Bernard A. O. D., having reported his arrival in Egypt, has been taken on the strength of the Army Occupation.
Captain W. R. Eden, R. H. A., has been granted leave of absence until December 4.
Kaimaskam K. D. W. Lloyd Bey has been appointed acting O. C., Kordofan district.

A marriage has been arranged between Mr. William Jackson Maltass, of Alexandria and Miss Gladys Maltass of Moda, Constantinople, and daughter of Mr. Thomas Maltass, Director of the Imperial Ottoman Fire Insurance Company.
The marriage of Mr. Maurice Laussac de Lagarenne to Louise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Lupus, will take place at St. Catherine's Church, Alexandria, on Saturday at 4.30 p.m.

We have much pleasure in announcing the marriage of Mr. Constant Gasparian with Miss Anna Bardisbarian, daughter of Mrs. Venve Bardisbarian, nee Sevasly, which recently took place in Smyrna amid a fashionable gathering of the elite of that town. The newly married couple arrived yesterday by the Khedivial S.S. "Osmanieh" and after being entertained at a gala banquet at the Windsor Hotel by the bride's uncle, Mr. Vahan Sevasly, Courtier on terrains, they proceeded to Cairo.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi)
div.p: Que cela provienne des cours de Paris qui noua soot arrivés en baisse ou de la tendance générale à réaliser de la part de nos spéculateurs à courte échéance, le lait est que la tenue de notre marché a été mauvaise oe matin. L'é|ément vendeur a dominé pendant toute la séance, sans réussir d'ailleurs à se défaire de quantités appréciables. lies échangea, diaséminén un peu sur toute la cote, n'ont eu aucune im-portance, même sur les titres les plus en vogue. Au surplus, la tendance est j>oar la faiblesse, à moine que Paris ou Londres ne fiassent renaître par une hausse opportune la confiance un instant ébranlée Ce qu'il y a de remarquable, c'est qu'avec une allure semblable la cote n'ait que peu souffert.

A l'ouverture, il n'était question que de Kaehler Hotel' à 6 1/4 et Comptoir à 3 1/8, prix auxquels quelques petits paquet* ont changé de mains; plus tard le* acheteurs, impressionné sans doute par l'allure de l'en semble, ont disparu. Les oonrs du Comptoir ont fini à 3 1/8 l'action ancienne, 3 5/32 la nouvelle et 2 1/8 la fondateur, contre 3 8/16, 3 1/4 et 2 1/4 hier,. En Béhéra one forte de mande a régné durant toute la séance, mais les vendeurs étant rares, les transactions n'ont pas eu d'extension. Le prix a haussé de 23 1/2 à 23 3/4 acheteurs. A part l'Agricole, qui a été quelque peu traitée, les valeurs dirigeantes ont été négligées. Quelques affaires insigni fientes ont en lieu en Rit* Hotels, United, Cassa di Soon to et Union Foncière.

L'Agricole a rétrogradé de 8 7/16 à 8 3/8, la National Bank de 22 1/16 à 21 7/8, la Daim de 13 7/8 à 13 3/4, l'obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 256 1/2 À 256 et le* Lota Turcs de 165 à 160 ; seule parmi le* valeur* diri géantes la Delta Light a progresse de 10 1/4 a 10 5/16. Encore la Differed a t elle fléchi dp 7 5/8 5 7 1/2.
En baisse encore la Banque d'Athènes de 111 à 110 12, le* Nungovich Hotel* de 17 1/2 à 17, la Land Bank de 7 5/16 à 7 3/8, l'Cnion Foncière de 5 5 4 15/16 et la Banque d' trient de 120 A 119 1/2.

Parmi leu titres d'ordre inférieur, la Cassa di Sconto a également rerulé de 54 1/2 à 54, la Building Landa de 2 14 à 2 1/8, la Delta Ijand de 1 21/32 à 1 5/M, la fondateur l'nited de 1 7/16 à 1 5/16 et lea Ritz Hotels de 5 m à 9/16. La Levieo est offerte À 1/2.
Sur le -este de la cote il n*y a pas de chan-gements à signaler.
Il a été vendu aux enchères publiques 100 Oasis (Corporation of Western Egypt) à 31/64 et 200 Hooker Land and General Trust à 13/32

Il semble de pl un en plus établi par lew revi Yemen to soudains de la tendance locale an moindre souffle venant d'Europe que les échan gea, d'ailleurs réduito à leur plus simple ex pression par l'ibolition du marché a terme, sont le liait de spéculateurs à courte échéance qui n'ont pour tout souci en acquérant de* titres que de réaliser eu quelques jours un petit bénéfice De là le mouvement actuel de tout petits paquets sur des titres favoris, c'est à dire sujets d'un jbur à l'autre à des fluctuations plus ou moinl sensibles. Cela ]»eut bien faire le compte de certains professionnels, mais lépargne doit se tenir sur ses gardes afin de ne pas rester comme l'an paxxé dernière détentrice "to hold the child," comme disent Ira anglais.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES BY CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'eeoompte libre * Londres qui avait haussé vendredi dernier de 1 /4 eut rest samedi in varié à 4 1/4 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, lee Conaolidée anglais ont baiaaé vendredi de 1/8 à 82 7'8 et l'Uni fiée de 1/4 à 102 8/4. La National Bauk a oon serré non avance de 8/8 à 22 3/8. L'Agricole et la Dalra qui avaient bénéficié vendredi de 1/8 ont été soutenus samedi à 8 5/8 et 14 re> pectivement. La Delta Light a été ferme à 10
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu I franc à 699 1a Banque d'Athénee est restée inchangée à 112. Ias Lot* Tares ont fléchi à 167

Ici, nous avons eu uneséance de realisations, On etait vendeur sur toute la ligne et c'est tout juste ai la fermeté du groupe égyptien à Londres a permis à nos valeurs dirigeantes de se consolider avec une légère avance. A vrai dire, les affaires ont été peu nombreuses et les ven deurs ont eu beau jeu pour causer les cours. Cependant il est bon dénoter que les reculs sont peu importants et sur quelques valeurs seulement, tandis que les valeurs déjà favori séea ces derniers jouta, ont de nouveau béné ficié de légères plus values.

Dans 1s compartiment des Banques, la Na tional Bank gagne 1/16 à 2*2 1/16 L'Agricole suit à 9 7/16 Le Comptoir Financier hausse à 3 1/4 et sa fondateur À 2 1/2. Les H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. se tassent par suite de l'envoi des "lettres de rappel" aux actionnaires qni n'ont pas effectué lea versements en retard, s exposant ainsi à I application des art 20et 21 dee Statute. Cette baisse ne saurait être, ainsi qu'il arrive généralement en semblables circonstances, que momentanée
Lea Jouimaaoes Baux du Caire, reculent à 19». Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien se consolide à OM, son obligation ancienne fait 302-303 et la nouvelle 255-256 La Béhérs continue sa

hausse à £ 28 1/1. La fondateur Allotment est en progrès à P.T. 63 L'Enterprise and Development tombe à 8 1/8 et sa fondateur à 12. L'Union Foncière se relève lentement à 4 16/16 Les Entreprises Immobilière* et Travanx *n binent l'influence du marché, l'action revient à 2 3 8 et la part à P. T. 46.
Lee Hélinpolis mollissent à 238 et lee (tarts à 11. L action Menialeli est en meilleure disposition à 2 3/8, tandis que les Frigorifiques tombent à 2 1 z2.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovieh se sont inscrites à 18 nominal et les Baehler progressent À 6 1/16 1/8.

Parmi Ica petites valeurs, la Delta ^and tombe à l 5/8 11/16 et la New Egyptian à 13z3. Lea Salt and Soda sont demandées à 18/6. Les Egyptian Constructions fléchissent à OA 16 3/8 et les United Lands à() 14-5 16.
Nous lisons dans le supplement a la Cote Hebdomadaire Legrelle et Co. (Anvers, Bruxelles et Paris) les lignes suivantes concernant l'Egypte:

"CHRONIQUE EGYPTIENNE.-A me sure qu'approche le début de la cam pagne financière en Egypte, nos prévisions se réalisant peu à peu. Sorties de la torpeur ou les avaient plongée» et maintenues la crise et la saison d'été, les valeurs égyptiennes trouvent déjà un regain défaveur qui attire sur elles l'attention des capitalistes, d'autant plus que tous les autres compartiments du marché sont dé laissés et voient les cours s effriter de plus en plus sans que les capitaux de placement inter viennent Tout le contraire se produit pour les valeurs égyptiennes ; rassurés par toutes le^ indications qui dénotant une situation saine enEgypte,et par la récolte importante de coton dont la négociation va faire entrer en Egypte d'importante bénéfices, les acheteurs se portent sur les grandes valeurs , la National Bank of Egypt que nous laissions la semaine dernière à £21 monte à £ M 12. le Crédit Foncier Egyptien fait preuve de grande fermeté et doit être mis en portefeuille au cours actuel car celui-ci laisse nneimportante marge à la hausse, l'action Agricultural Bank of Egvpt avance graduellement à H 5/K."

"Peu à peu les autre* valeurs suivent le mouvement ; par la force de leur valeur propre le* titres des bonnes ivimpagnie* retrouveront des cotation* normales bien supérieure* aux oour* actuels. Si ce mouvement se fait lente ment et graduellement, sans intervention brus que de la spéculation, ce sera tant mieux car ce sera et plus sûr et plus durable."

" A lappui de ce que nous n avons ('easé de répéter tant en ce qui roncemç les ressources financières de l'Egypte que le caractère réel de la crise qui a atteint le marché égyptien, nous constatons le ancrés que rencontre l'émission de 100,000 obligations Crédit Foncier Egyptien 3 % à 890 francs. Cette émission fera rentrer encore une quarantaine de millions dans le fays et d'autre part la National Bank of Egypt an nonce l'émission prochaine de 50,000 actions nouvelles de £ 10 A £ 90. Ce qui mettra encore 25 millions de francs à la disposition des marchés égyptiens. Et ce sont là de* ressources permanentes augmentant la circulation moné taire du pays et non des importations d'or des tinéea au paiement de* récoltes et qui for cément rentrent en partie dan* leur pays d'ori gine."
" Tout cela est de natura renforcer notre conviction: une repirse des affaires resultera de toutes ces circonstances. "
Carnet de l'actionnaire.
MM. les actionnaires «Lela ''Société Générale •le pressage et de Dépôts" sont convoqués en assemblée générale ordinaire le lundi 2N Octobre courant à * heures p .ni. au siège de la Société.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Applications (in writing only) for places as clerks in the Sudan Branch of the Egyptian Irrigation Service will be received at the Ministry of Public Works up to the 25th October by the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan.
Some educational qualifications and a good knowledge of English is essential. Pay L.E. 8 to L.E. 15 per month according to qualifications.

Applications should state qualifications and experience and give references and should be accompanied by copies of certificates; and should be addressed to the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan, Public Works Ministry, Cairo, in envelopes labelled "Application for post of clerk."

div.head:
THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
MULAY HAFID'S FORCE.
PLUNDERING SURRENDERED TRIBES

div.p: M. Regnault is in constant conference with the Grand Vizier and the Foreign Minister.
Reuter
Mulay Hafid's force, under Mulay Ragahid, is plundering the tribes which have submitted to the French.
(Reuter)
M. Regnault and General Liautey have conferred with Ben Sliman of the police on the South Oran frontier. Ben Sliman promised that he would do his utmost to prevent further pillaging.
(Havas)
The newspapers announce that Colonel Santa Olalla, commanding the Spanish contingent at Casablanca, will be recalled.
(Havas)
Mulay Hafid's envoys have called at the Foreign Office but have not be admitted.

The "Times" learns that France and Spain are about to issue a joint circular to the Powers stating that the Sultan has ceded to them the right of policing the Moroccan coast and waters against contraband.
(Reuter)

div.head:
MR. WINSTON CHURCHILL.
THE OCCUPATION OF CYPRUS.

div.p: Mr. Winston Churchill has sailed for Port Said.

Replying to deputations of Moslems and Greeks with reference to the union of Cyprus with Greece, he said that while the Government respects the national sentiments of both races the idea of abandoning the island or altering the political status could not be entertained. The Government, however, would try to remove all reasonable grounds of complaint. The Moslem deputations testified to their loyalty to Britain and to their contentment under heir rule.
(Reuter)

div.head:
TURCO-PERSIAN DISPUTE.
CONCENTRATION OF TURKISH TROOPS.

div.p: The Porte, replying to the Persian Ambassador, has denied the violation of Persian territory and declared that the entire Baradosht district is Ottoman territory. Persia is alarmed at the concentration of Turkish troops at Kanchin, which is interpreted as threatening fresh incursions.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE AMERICAN NAVY.
TOUR OF CRUISERS.

div.p: The cruisers "Tennessee" and "Washington" have left Hampton for the Pacific. They have inaugurated the battleship cruise and will sail round the coast of South America to Magdalena Bay, where they will take part in manceuvres with the cruisers "California" and "South Dakota."
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE FLOODS IN FRANCE.
A TRAGIC INCIDENT.

div.p: A tragic incident occurred at Ameliedes Bains, near Perpignan, on Saturday night. The river invaded a villa seven occupants of which took refuge on the roof. Their cries attracted attention, but the torrent was impassible and the villa gradually crumbled away. All were drowned before a helpless crowd.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE RAILWAY CRISIS.
ASSOCIATIONS REPLY TO BELL.

div.p: The Railway Companies' Assocations have replied to Mr. Bell that the Companies are unanimous that no advantage would arise if the conference was subject to the meaning and recognition of Mr. Bell's speeches, the letters from the Companies individually having made misapprehension impossible.
The shares of Home Railways fell on the Stock Market.

The Scottish Railways, acting jointly, have directed that men's notices will be accepted immediately when tendered and none re-engaged. They are sanguine of victory. Mr. Bell in the course of an interview said that he would not approach the Board of Trade as he was snubbed by it in 1897.
(Reuter)

div.head:
GREEK OFFICERS IN CRETE.
AN ENTHUSIASTIC RECEPTION.

div.p: The Greek officers have arrived. They met with an enthusiastic reception from the populace and the authorities. Cheers were given for the union and the Greek army. They were afterwards received by the High Commissioner. The town was illuminated in the evening.
(Reuter)

The Minister, M. Simopoulos, speaking at the laying of the foundations of the two new cities, dwelt on the persecutions of the Greeks in Bulgaria and said that it was the duty of the Government of a free state to offer a home to the persecuted.
(Reuter)
The Crown Prince was to-day admitted to the Ministry of Interior for a year's study of the working of the administration.
(Reuter)
The Crown Prince will assume functions for a year in the Ministry of the Interior in order to perfect his administrative training.
(Havas)
Sir J. L. Harrington has been married at Manchester (Massachusetts) to Amy, daughter of the late Senator Macmillan of Michigan.
(Reuter)
M. Caillaux declared to the Budget Commission that the deficit was 28 millions
(Havas)
The Emperor's condition is encouraging. His Majest received in audience Baron von Aehrenthal for 45 minutes yesterday.
(Reuter)
The state of the Emperor is better.
(Havas)
The strikes have ended. The Prefect of the city having dismissed several of the officials and arrested the carabineers who shot the strikers.
(Reuter)

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM.
div.p: Not long ago an alarmist article appeared in one of the reviews with regard to the Pan Islamic peril. The writer went ao for as to declare that within the next generation every Christian would have been cleared out of Africa by the followers of El Senoussi, the new Mahdi. It is rather comforting, therefore, to read some thing on the other ride The Constantinople correspondent of the "Birmingham Daily Post" has had an interesting conversation with a high official of the Porte, who, though expressing sympathy with the political ideals of the Young Turin, ridiculed the Pan-Islamic movement He maintained that there could never be any close affinity between the various Moslem sects. "We see Christian States at war with each other, and so we shall ever see enmity between Moslem States. At the present moment we have our own troubles with the Shiahs of Persia and the Sunnis of Yemen. Think you that we should tolerate the religious over lordship of the so-called Mahdis of the Senoussi !" Then he reminded his interviewer that the Sultan's claim to the Caliphate is contested by Persia and Morocco, and only tacitly acquiesced in by the Shareef of Mecca, while it it ignored by the Ameers of Bokhara and Afghanistan ; and finally he declared that "there are many of us who believe that there ran be no peace in Islam until the temporal power is divorced from the religious power, and the Caliphs of Islam reduced to the role of the Popes of Rome, and their authority restricted to the two cities of Mecca and Medina." We have no notion, of course, of the amount of credence to be attached to the high official whose opinions are quoted, but, considering the vast number of Mahometans who are the faithful subjects of King Edward, the statements made are decidedly interesting, and so far as they go reassuring.

The following is the account of the interview. I had a long and most interesting conversa tion this afternoon with a high official at the Sublime Porte, a gentleman of Liberal views, and evidently in deep sympathy, if not in close correspondence, with the members of that section of the Young Turkey party which has its headquarters in Paris. Indeed, my friend was good enough to give me copies of the organs published by that society One of these, the "Mechvcret," is published in French under the editorship of a certain Ahmed Riza, a gentleman who bears the reputation of the most impeccable honesty ; the other, the "Tereke," is published in Turkish, and is edit ed by Kenan Bey, a young man, I understand, of great promise. Under the strict press laws in thia country and the strict police espionage at the foreign post offices in this city, the entry of these journals into Turkey is forbidden. Nevertheless, my friend informed me, large numbers do find their way into the country, and are clandestinely passed from hand to hand, thus diffusing a certain amount of very diluted Liberalism into this most Conserva tive of countries. The watchword of the "Young Turkey party" is "Turkey for the Turks," and Ahmed Riza and his colleagues appear to be of opinion that the gift of a "Constitution" will cure all ills. It is a very open question whether Turkey is ripe for such a change, and I have hoard arguments for and against a Parliament advanced by men of very liberal ideas. Some maintain that the country is ripe tor a Parlia ment ; others that the first step most be to form an Administrative Council endowed with wide powers, restore Ministers to their old responsi bilities, and, by means of municipal councils, train the people gradually to a system of po pular government. All save the immediate entourage of the Sultan are agreed that the present form of Government is working incalculable harm.

Although my friend was so far in sympathy with the views of the "Mechveret" as to wish to see his country freed from foreign control and take her stand amongst the Greet Powers, he is clear headed enough to see that this cannot be accomplished by merely flooding the country with newspaper articles, whether couched in French or Turkish. Action, and strong action, is necessary, and this he feels to be almost beyond the bounds of possibility. The Turks, he went on to say, seem to have lost all power of initiative, and to be utterly incapable of organisation. They have been so poisoned by the Hamidean system of bribery and espionage that every man is afraid of his neighbour. Abd ul-Hamid has his secret police in every capital in Europe, and the sayings and doings of every Turk are daily reported to Yildiz. There are Pashas and Beys in Cairo, Paris London, and Geneva, who are supposed to have fled from the tyranny of Abd ul Hamid They are merely his agents, obtaining all information as to the ramifications of the various societies which aim at the establishment of a Constitution in Constantinople. Last year upwards of £100,000 was remitted to Munir Pasha, the Turkish Ambassador in Paris, for secret service money This man has the snr veillance of Turkish refugees in France, Belgium. Switzerland, and even in England.lt naturally is to his interest to make the most of a movement which as yet confines itself to newspaper articles devoted to attacks on Abd ul Hamid and the Western Powers. My friend has, or pretends to have, a warm admiration for England, and was good enough to say that in his belief, and in the belief of a large number of his friends, the salvation of Turkey could only be worked out in conjunction with Great Britain and the Moslems of India, and, whilst agreeing in the main with the Paris organs of the Young Turkish party, he deplored their anti-English bias He ridiculed the Pan Islamic movement, maintaining that there never could be any close affinity between the various Moslem sects. "We see Christian States at war with each other, and so we shall ever see enmity between Moslem States At the present moment we have our own troubles with the Shiahs of

Persia and the Sunnis of Yemen. Think you that we should tolerate the religions overlordship of the so-called Mahdis of the Se noussi? Were not the Mahdists of the Soudan as fanatically opposed to the Egyptians as to the English? The claims of the Sultans o. Turkey to the (Caliphate are contested by Persia and Morocco and only tacitly acquiesced in by the Shereefs of Mecca, whilst they are ignored by the Amirs of Bokhara and of Afghanistan . There may be young and fervent men who believe in Pan-Islamism just as in Christianity there may be fervent men who believe in the union of the Greek and the Roman with the Anglican churches ; but Popes and Patriarchs will each wish to wield supreme power, and communion in their eyes means submission to themselves. So it is with os. The Sultan believes in a Pan Islamism which recognises him as the supreme head of the Moslems to wield undivided power, temporal as well as religious. He looks to the reestablishment of his authority over the lost Moslem provinces of his empire and to the acceptance of his claim to the Caliphate by all Moslem States The day for this in past, and there are many of us who believe that there can be no peace in Islam until the temporal power is divorced from the religious power and the Caliphs of Islam reduced to the role of the Popes of Rome and their authority restricted to the two cities of Mecca and Medina."

My friend seems to believe that the feeling of nationality was deeper than that of religion, and a common language a greater bond of union that a common faith. With the spread of education be foresaw the spread of Nationalism and the final severance of the already loosening hold of the conquering Turk over his subject races. He believed that before long the Ottoman Empire would be split up into a number of first autonomous and then indepen dent States, Albania and Armenia, Arabia and Syria, and finally Kurdistan breaking away. My friend was not a Turk, and though a Moslew, for the Turk he professed the most profound contempt. "Look around," he said, "at our present statesmen. Study our past history. When once the Turk ceased his career of con quest and attempted to administer the lands he had overrun, he was compelled to call in foreign aid, and to depend on his subject races for his statesmen, and even for his generals. No Turk has come to the front for mote than two centuries. Osman Pasha, the famous de fender of Plevna, was a Bulgarian. Our present Grand Vizier is an Albanian. Tewfik Pasha, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, comes from the Crimea. Nourri Bey, the ablest diplomatist we have, is of French extraction. Even the Sultan is born of an Armenian mother The real Turk has been played out for many generations, whether as warrior or administrator, and no Pan-Islamic agitation will ever restore his lost qualities of energy, endurance, and honesty. Nor will it cause the Moslems of other lands to rally round the Sultan as the head of their faith. Take the Hamidick Hedja Railway as a case in point This was a scheme initiated by the Sultan for the purpose of alleviating the sufferings of Muslim pilgrims in their annual pilgrimage to Mecca Appeals were made to Moslems throughout the world, yet the sixty million Muslims of India have practically turned a deaf ear to their Caliph's missionaries and have only subscribed a few thousand pounds to an enterprise which the Sultan proclaims tn lie the noblest work undertaken in Islam since the death of the Prophet, and for the completion of which millions are required. Let me instance another case. A few months ago an Indian Mussulman came frequently to the Sublime Porte. He was the founder of the London Pan Islamic Society, and he was most anxious to obtain the patronage of the Sultan to a scheme for building a mosque in London. Needless to say. such a scheme could not be carried through without funds. Think yon that the Sultan, the Caliph of Indian Muslims, or the Sheikh el Islam, our Minister of Religion, subscribed one farthing towards this Pan Islamic undertaking? Not one! The Indian Moslems mint build their own mosque, the Turks their own railway ; Pan-Islamism is a chimera Would Indian Muslims who have tasted the liberty of British rule be content to live under such a despotism as ours ? Would we with our views of civilisation submit to the barbarism and fanaticism of the Senoussi ? Would the Nationalists of Egypt work hand in hand with the young Turks of Constantinople? Egypt for the Egyptians is their cry ; Turkey for the Turks that of Ahmed Riza and the "Mechveret!" But where is Turkey, and who are the Turks? It is possible that the Ottoman Empire may have a further span of life, if its component provinces are granted autonomy and if a (Central Administration Council is called into being, but our fate is doomed if the present one-man despotism is continued. Racial animosities are being kindled which all the Pan Islamism in the world wil never extinguish. Turks from Antolia and Syrians from Aleppo are poured

into Albania to overawe the mountaineers of of Ipek and Prizrend, whilst Albanians are transported to Yemen to restore order in those regions. Here in Constantinople we have the name fight for supremacy being daily waged, Syrian and Albanian striving to obtain the upper hand at Yildiz, where no pure Turk has a footing. Outside Yildiz all are agreed that no foreign foe at any epoch of our history has worked one tithe the evil to our country as Abd ul Hamid has achieved, yet we are unable to decide on a common course of action to enable us to redrew our wrongs Within the last week we have had serious disturbances in every barrack in Constantinople. The Minister of Finance has been openly threatened by officials of the highest rank. Loyalty is a bye word—rebellion and mutiny striving for an outlet. Yet we are forced to content ourselves with pouring our woes into the ears of strangers and in penning denun ciatory articles which are furtively passed from hand to band. And this is the extent of our efforts to obtain a measure of freedom! For the first time since be ascended the throne the Sultan has allowed his birthday to pass without directing that the officials should receive a month's pay. To you as an English man or to the natives under your rule in India, it sounds impossible that officials here should receive but six months' salary in the year. Hitherto these payments have been made on the Prophet's birthday, the first day of the Fast of the Ramzan on the Feasts of the Bairam, the Kourban Bairam, on the Sultan's accession, and on his birthday. This year no payment was made on the Prophet's birthday, which fell in March, and now none has been made on the Sultan's birthday, which occurs on September 23. So that officials will only receive four in lieu of six month's pay. No wonder then that troops are in a state of semi mutiny and officials in sullen discontent Had we but a leader there would be a rising tomorrow, tut no man has confidence in his brother. That an outbreak will occur, and that shortly, I am convinced. If the Yildiz Camarille is alive to its own interests it will be as bloodless a coup d'état as the one that removed Abd ul Axis from the throne. Otherwise the new Sultan will wade to power through a sea of blood, and Turkish domination in Europe be at an end."

I left the Sublime Porte convinced that though the "Moslem Menace" might be a catchy headline for a magazine article, it need not disturb the sleep of the most solitary Christian in Islamic lands. A house divided against itself cannot stand.

div.head: THE NAUTCH GIRL.
div.p: The position of the nautch girl is no longer what it was in the Indian social system. Not merely Europeans but some of the best among the natives feel that in view of the gradual raising of the tone of society, the evils associated with her profession should cease to enjoy the toleration accorded to them in the past

This view, however, is by no means universal, and the conflict of opinion is strikingly illustrated by the experience of Gaubar Jan, a well known nautch girl of Calcutta, and one of the finest native singera in India. A rich Marwari family of Bombay recently engaged her to per form at a marriage ceremony, paying her a fee of Rs15,000 (£1,000). Later she visited the Lady Northcote Hindu Orphanage, and con sented to sing in its aid gratis in the town hall The citizens of Bombay, male and female, flocked in large numbers to listen to her, as the gramophone has made her name a household word in India The handsome sum of £400 was collected on the spot for the orphanage. At the close of the assembly the Hon Sir M Perozeshah Mehta pinned a medal on her breast.

Hearing this, Mr. Justice Chandravarkar, of Bombay, a well-known social reformer and Brahmin leader, ceased his connection with the managing committee. A hot newspaper discussion has followed. Mr. Tilak and other have writte in defence of Sir M. Mehta, while other correspondents are against him. On another occasion Gaubar Jan sang in aid of the Mohammedan College of Aligarbm but Nawab Mohsan-ul-Mulk refused to received any profit from that source.
